title: 3  Homework Problems 1 (Vectors)
text:
3.1 Problem 1 (Vector algebra)
The following vectors are given:
\[
\mathbf{a}= \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}, \qquad \mathbf{b}=\begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 4 \\ -5 \end{bmatrix}, \qquad \mathbf{c} = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 6.5 \\ -7 \end{bmatrix}.
\]
Find the values of:

title: 3  Homework Problems 1 (Vectors)
text:
3.2 Problem 2 (Translation office)
A translation office translated [ =[24,, 17,, 9,, 13] ] documents from English, French, German and Russian, respectively. For each language, it takes about [ =[5,, 10,, 11,, 7] ] minutes to translate one page.

How much time did they spend translating in total? How much did each of the translators spend on average if there are 4 translators in the office?

Write an expression for this amount in terms of the vectors () and ().

title: 3  Homework Problems 1 (Vectors)
text:
3.3 Problem 3 (Norms)
Calculate the Manhattan (L1) and Euclidean (L2) norms of the following vectors:

a) (=
\[\begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -9 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}\]
),
b) (-2), where [ =
\[\begin{bmatrix}3 \\ 4 \\ 1 \\ 0\end{bmatrix}\]
,=
\[\begin{bmatrix}4 \\ 5 \\ -2 \\ -1\end{bmatrix}\]
, ]
c) (-3), where [ =
\[\begin{bmatrix}2 \\ -5 \\ 6\end{bmatrix}\]
. ]

title: 3  Homework Problems 1 (Vectors)
text:
3.4 Problem 4 (angle between vectors)
Find the angles between the following vectors:

a) (=
\[\begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\]
) and (=
\[\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}\]
),
b) The vectors () and () from the previous problem.

title: 3  Homework Problems 1 (Vectors)
text:
3.5 Problem 5 (Matrix vector product)
What vectors do you get by applying the matrix
\[
A = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & -3 \\ 3 & 3 \end{bmatrix}
\]
to the vectors:

a) (=
\[\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\]
),
b) (=
\[\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\]
),
c) (=
\[\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\]
)?

(Additional:) Draw the vectors before and after multiplying with (A). What can you say visually about the matrix? Can you guess how it will act on the vector ([2 ])?

title: 3  Homework Problems 1 (Vectors)
text:
3.6 Problem 6 (Matrix algebra)
Compute the following products:

a) (AB), where [ A=
\[\begin{bmatrix} 6 & 5 \\ -2 & 7 \end{bmatrix}\]
,B=
\[\begin{bmatrix} -5 & 3 \\ 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\]
, ]
b) ((A-B)(A+B)), where [ A=
\[\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 2 & 4 \\ -3 & -2 & 4 \\ -2 & 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\]
,B=
\[\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 & 3 \\ -1 & 2 & 2 \\ 1 & 4 & -1 \end{bmatrix}\]
, ]
c) (A^2 - B^2) with the same (A) and (B) as in b).

title: 3  Homework Problems 1 (Vectors)
text:
3.7 Problem 7 (Geometric interpretation of matrix multiplication)
Consider the following matrix (called the shear matrix):
\[
S = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}
\]
Answer the following:

a) What do you get if you apply (S) to the vector ([0 ])?
b) What do you get if you apply (S) again on the result of the previous point?
c) What if you apply (S) one more time?
d) What do you think happens when we apply (S) 100 times to that vector?
e) Can you compute (S^{100})?

title: 3  Homework Problems 1 (Vectors)
text:
3.8 Problem 8 (Vector space)
Determine whether or not the following sets (with usual addition and scalar multiplication) are vector spaces:

a) [ A = {
\[\begin{bmatrix} a \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\]
a }, ]
b) [ B = {
\[\begin{bmatrix} a \\ -a \end{bmatrix}\]
a }. ]
c) (A = ),
d) [ B = {
\[\begin{bmatrix} a \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\]
a }. ]

Hint: If you want to proof that something is not a vector space you can try to show that there are some “bad” elements, such that if we add them or multiply them by a scalar (not necessarily positive), the result would not belong to the set.
